PI_organization: Cooperative Institute for Research in Environmental Sciences, University of Colorado
project_description: Soils harbor enormously diverse bacterial populations, and soil bacterial communities can vary greatly in composition across space. However, our understanding of the specific changes in soil bacterial community structure that occur across larger spatial scales is limited because most previous work has focused on either surveying a relatively small number of soils in detail or analyzing a larger number of soils with techniques that provide little detail about the phylogenetic structure of the bacterial communities. Here we used a bar-coded pyrosequencing technique to characterize bacterial communities in 88 soils from across North and South America, obtaining an average of 1,501 sequences per soil. We found that overall bacterial community composition, as measured by pairwise UniFrac distances, was significantly correlated with differences in soil pH (r = 0.79), largely driven by changes in the relative abundances of Acidobacteria, Actinobacteria, and Bacteroidetes across the range of soil pHs. In addition, soil pH explains a significant portion of the variability associated with observed changes in the phylogenetic structure within each dominant lineage. The overall phylogenetic diversity of the bacterial communities was also correlated with soil pH (R2 = 0.50), with peak diversity in soils with near-neutral pHs. Together, these results suggest that the structure of soil bacterial communities is predictable, to some degree, across larger spatial scales, and the effect of soil pH on bacterial community composition is evident at even relatively coarse levels of taxonomic resolution.
study_abstract: Soils harbor enormously diverse bacterial populations, and soil bacterial communities can vary greatly in composition across space. However, our understanding of the specific changes in soil bacterial community structure that occur across larger spatial scales is limited because most previous work has focused on either surveying a relatively small number of soils in detail or analyzing a larger number of soils with techniques that provide little detail about the phylogenetic structure of the bacterial communities. Here we used a bar-coded pyrosequencing technique to characterize bacterial communities in 88 soils from across North and South America, obtaining an average of 1,501 sequences per soil. We found that overall bacterial community composition, as measured by pairwise UniFrac distances, was significantly correlated with differences in soil pH (r = 0.79), largely driven by changes in the relative abundances of Acidobacteria, Actinobacteria, and Bacteroidetes across the range of soil pHs. In addition, soil pH explains a significant portion of the variability associated with observed changes in the phylogenetic structure within each dominant lineage. The overall phylogenetic diversity of the bacterial communities was also correlated with soil pH (R2 = 0.50), with peak diversity in soils with near-neutral pHs. Together, these results suggest that the structure of soil bacterial communities is predictable, to some degree, across larger spatial scales, and the effect of soil pH on bacterial community composition is evident at even relatively coarse levels of taxonomic resolution.
project_funding: National Science Foundation (MCB0610970 and DBI0301773) and the Andrew W. Mellon Foundation.

isol_growth_condt.definition: Publication reference in the form of pubmed ID (pmid), digital object identifier (doi) or url for isolation of the sample

samp_size.definition: Amount or size of sample (volume, mass or area) that was collected, along with the unit used

continent.definition: The geographical origin of the sample as defined by continent.  Use one of: Africa, Antarctica, Asia, Australia, Europe, North America, South America

biome.definition: The environmental biome represents the major classes of ecologically similar communities of plants, animals, and other organisms. Biomes are defined based on factors such as plant structures, leaf types, plant spacing, and other factors like climate. Examples include: desert, taiga, deciduous woodland, or coral reef. EnvO terms listed under environmental biome can be found from the link: http://bioportal.bioontology.org/visualize/1069/?conceptid=ENVO%3A00000428

samp_collect_device.definition: The method or device employed for isolating/collecting the sample
samp_collect_device.value:
A total of 98 soil samples that were distinct with respect to soil and site characteristics were collected from a wide array of ecosystem types in North and South America (see Table 3). Only soils unsaturated for the majority of the year were examined. Soils were collected near the height of the plant growing season at each location. To examine whether seasonal variation was important, an additional set of soil samples was collected 6 months after the initial collection at a subset of sites. At each site, the upper 5 cm of mineral soil was collected from 5-10 locations within a given plot of ≈100 m2 and composited into a single bulk sample. All soil samples were shipped to the University of California, Santa Barbara, within a few days of collection, where they were sieved to 4 mm, homogenized, and archived at -80C.

Approximately 10 g of soil from each site was homogenized in a mortar and pestle with liquid N2, and DNAs were extracted from a 0.5-g subsample by use of a MoBio PowerSoil DNA extraction kit following the manufacturer's instructions, with an additional incubation step at 65C for 10 min followed by 2 min of bead beating to limit DNA shearing. Eluted DNAs were stored at −20C.

temperature.definition: Temperature of the sample in celsius at time of sampling

collection_date.definition: The date of sampling. Use ISO8601 compliant format, ie. 2008-01-23

altitude.definition: The altitude of the sample is the vertical distance in meters between Earth's surface above Sea Level and the sampled position in the air.

feature.definition: Environmental feature level includes geographic environmental features. Examples include: harbor, cliff, or lake. EnvO terms listed under environmental feature can be found from the link: http://bioportal.bioontology.org/visualize/1069/?conceptid=ENVO%3A00002297

location.definition: The geographical origin of the sample as defined by the specific local region name

sample_name.definition: Unique name or id of the sample

latitude.definition: The geographical origin of the sample as defined by latitude. The value should be reported in decimal degrees and in WGS84 system

elevation.definition: The elevation of the sampling site in meters as measured by the vertical distance from mean sea level.

material.definition: The environmental material level refers to the matter that was displaced by the sample, prior to the sampling event. Environmental matter terms are generally mass nouns. Examples include: air, soil, or water. EnvO terms listed under environmental matter can be found from the link: http://bioportal.bioontology.org/visualize/1069/?conceptid=ENVO%3A00010483

collection_timezone.definition: The timezone of sampling.  Use ISO8601 compliant format, ie. UTC-7

country.definition: The geographical origin of the sample as defined by the country or sea name. Country or sea names should be chosen from the INSDC country list (http://insdc.org/country.html), or the GAZ ontology (http://bioportal.bioontology.org/visualize/1397)

env_package.definition: MIGS/MIMS/MIMARKS extension for reporting of measurements and observations obtained from one or more of the environments where the sample was obtained. Use one of: air, host-associated, human-associated, human-skin, human-oral, human-gut, human-vaginal, microbial mat|biofilm, miscellaneous, plant-associated, sediment, soil, wastewater|sludge, water

longitude.definition: The geographical origin of the sample as defined by longitude. The value should be reported in decimal degrees and in WGS84 system

depth.definition: Depth is defined as the vertical distance in meters below surface, e.g. for sediment or soil samples depth is measured from sediment or soil surface, respectivly.

collection_time.definition: The local time of sampling.  Use ISO8601 compliant format, ie. 19:23:10

reverse_primers.definition: List of reverse PCR primers that were used to amplify the sequence of the targeted gene, locus or subfragment

metagenome_name.definition: Unique name for the sequences from this library

reverse_barcodes.definition: List of barcodes attached to reverse primers
reverse_barcodes.value: 338R primer contained a 12-bp bar-code sequence, a TC linker, and a Roche 454 B sequencing adapter

seq_meth.definition: Sequencing method used. Use one of: Sanger, pyrosequencing, ABI-solid, 454, Illumina, assembeled, other

forward_barcodes.definition: List of barcodes attached to forward primers

investigation_type.definition: Library construction type. This field is either metagenome for whole genome shotgun sequencing or mimarks-survey for amplicon/16S rRNA sequencing

sample_name.definition: Unique name or id of the sample the library is derived from

seq_center.definition: Name of instatute sequencing was done

target_gene.definition: Targeted gene or locus name for marker gene studies; e.g. 16S rRNA, 18S rRNA, nif, amoA, rpo

forward_primers.definition: List of forward PCR primers that were used to amplify the sequence of the targeted gene, locus or subfragment

EnvO terms listed under environmental biome can be found from the link: http://bioportal.bioontology.org/visualize/1069/?conceptid=ENVO%3A00000428

samp_collect_device.definition: The method or device employed for isolating/collecting the sample
samp_collect_device.value:
A total of 98 soil samples that were distinct with respect to soil and site characteristics were collected from a wide array of ecosystem types in North and South America (see Table 3). Only soils unsaturated for the majority of the year were examined. Soils were collected near the height of the plant growing season at each location. To examine whether seasonal variation was important, an additional set of soil samples was collected 6 months after the initial collection at a subset of sites. At each site, the upper 5 cm of mineral soil was collected from 5ÃÂ10 locations within a given plot of ≈100 m2 and composited into a single bulk sample. All soil samples were shipped to the University of California, Santa Barbara, within a few days of collection, where they were sieved to 4 mm, homogenized, and archived at ÃÂ80ÃÂ°C.

Approximately 10 g of soil from each site was homogenized in a mortar and pestle with liquid N2, and DNAs were extracted from a 0.5-g subsample by use of a MoBio PowerSoil DNA extraction kit following the manufacturer's instructions, with an additional incubation step at 65ÃÂ°C for 10 min followed by 2 min of bead beating to limit DNA shearing. Eluted DNAs were stored at −20ÃÂ°C.

material.definition: The environmental material level refers to the matter that was displaced by the sample, prior to the sampling event. Environmental matter terms are generally mass nouns. Examples include: air, soil, or water. EnvO terms listed under environmental matter can be found from the link: http://bioportal.bioontology.org/visualize/1069/?conceptid=ENVO%3A00010483

elevation.definition: The elevation of the sampling site in meters as measured by the vertical distance from mean sea level.

collection_timezone.definition: The timezone of sampling.  Use ISO8601 compliant format, ie. UTC-7

collection_date.definition: The date of sampling. Use ISO8601 compliant format, ie. 2008-01-23

country.definition: The geographical origin of the sample as defined by the country or sea name. Country or sea names should be chosen from the INSDC country list (http://insdc.org/country.html), or the GAZ ontology (http://bioportal.bioontology.org/visualize/1397)

altitude.definition: The altitude of the sample is the vertical distance in meters between Earth's surface above Sea Level and the sampled position in the air.

env_package.definition: MIGS/MIMS/MIMARKS extension for reporting of measurements and observations obtained from one or more of the environments where the sample was obtained. Use one of: air, host-associated, human-associated, human-skin, human-oral, human-gut, human-vaginal, microbial mat|biofilm, miscellaneous, plant-associated, sediment, soil, wastewater|sludge, water

feature.definition: Environmental feature level includes geographic environmental features. Examples include: harbor, cliff, or lake. EnvO terms listed under environmental feature can be found from the link: http://bioportal.bioontology.org/visualize/1069/?conceptid=ENVO%3A00002297

longitude.definition: The geographical origin of the sample as defined by longitude. The value should be reported in decimal degrees and in WGS84 system

isol_growth_condt.definition: Publication reference in the form of pubmed ID (pmid), digital object identifier (doi) or url for isolation of the sample

depth.definition: Depth is defined as the vertical distance in meters below surface, e.g. for sediment or soil samples depth is measured from sediment or soil surface, respectivly.

location.definition: The geographical origin of the sample as defined by the specific local region name

sample_name.definition: Unique name or id of the sample

latitude.definition: The geographical origin of the sample as defined by latitude. The value should be reported in decimal degrees and in WGS84 system

samp_size.definition: Amount or size of sample (volume, mass or area) that was collected, along with the unit used

continent.definition: The geographical origin of the sample as defined by continent.  Use one of: Africa, Antarctica, Asia, Australia, Europe, North America, South America

collection_time.definition: The local time of sampling.  Use ISO8601 compliant format, ie. 19:23:10

reverse_primers.definition: List of reverse PCR primers that were used to amplify the sequence of the targeted gene, locus or subfragment

metagenome_name.definition: Unique name for the sequences from this library

reverse_barcodes.definition: List of barcodes attached to reverse primers
reverse_barcodes.value: 338R primer contained a 12-bp bar-code sequence, a TC linker, and a Roche 454 B sequencing adapter

seq_meth.definition: Sequencing method used. Use one of: Sanger, pyrosequencing, ABI-solid, 454, Illumina, assembeled, other

forward_barcodes.definition: List of barcodes attached to forward primers

investigation_type.definition: Library construction type. This field is either metagenome for whole genome shotgun sequencing or mimarks-survey for amplicon/16S rRNA sequencing

sample_name.definition: Unique name or id of the sample the library is derived from

seq_center.definition: Name of instatute sequencing was done

target_gene.definition: Targeted gene or locus name for marker gene studies; e.g. 16S rRNA, 18S rRNA, nif, amoA, rpo

forward_primers.definition: List of forward PCR primers that were used to amplify the sequence of the targeted gene, locus or subfragment

biome.definition: The environmental biome represents the major classes of ecologically similar communities of plants, animals, and other organisms. Biomes are defined based on factors such as plant structures, leaf types, plant spacing, and other factors like climate. Examples include: desert, taiga, deciduous woodland, or coral reef. EnvO terms listed under environmental biome can be found from the link: http://bioportal.bioontology.org/visualize/1069/?conceptid=ENVO%3A00000428

samp_collect_device.definition: The method or device employed for isolating/collecting the sample
samp_collect_device.value:
A total of 98 soil samples that were distinct with respect to soil and site characteristics were collected from a wide array of ecosystem types in North and South America (see Table 3). Only soils unsaturated for the majority of the year were examined. Soils were collected near the height of the plant growing season at each location. To examine whether seasonal variation was important, an additional set of soil samples was collected 6 months after the initial collection at a subset of sites. At each site, the upper 5 cm of mineral soil was collected from 5-10 locations within a given plot of ≈100 m2 and composited into a single bulk sample. All soil samples were shipped to the University of California, Santa Barbara, within a few days of collection, where they were sieved to 4 mm, homogenized, and archived at -80C.

Approximately 10 g of soil from each site was homogenized in a mortar and pestle with liquid N2, and DNAs were extracted from a 0.5-g subsample by use of a MoBio PowerSoil DNA extraction kit following the manufacturer's instructions, with an additional incubation step at 65C for 10 min followed by 2 min of bead beating to limit DNA shearing. Eluted DNAs were stored at −20C.

biome.definition: The environmental biome represents the major classes of ecologically similar communities of plants, animals, and other organisms. samp_collect_device.definition: The method or device employed for isolating/collecting the sample
samp_collect_device.value:
A total of 98 soil samples that were distinct with respect to soil and site characteristics were collected from a wide array of ecosystem types in North and South America (see Table 3). Only soils unsaturated for the majority of the year were examined. Soils were collected near the height of the plant growing season at each location. To examine whether seasonal variation was important, an additional set of soil samples was collected 6 months after the initial collection at a subset of sites. At each site, the upper 5 cm of mineral soil was collected from 5ÃÂ10 locations within a given plot of ≈100 m2 and composited into a single bulk sample. All soil samples were shipped to the University of California, Santa Barbara, within a few days of collection, where they were sieved to 4 mm, homogenized, and archived at ÃÂ80ÃÂ°C.

Approximately 10 g of soil from each site was homogenized in a mortar and pestle with liquid N2, and DNAs were extracted from a 0.5-g subsample by use of a MoBio PowerSoil DNA extraction kit following the manufacturer's instructions, with an additional incubation step at 65ÃÂ°C for 10 min followed by 2 min of bead beating to limit DNA shearing. Eluted DNAs were stored at −20ÃÂ°C.

material.definition: The environmental material level refers to the matter that was displaced by the sample, prior to the sampling event. Environmental matter terms are generally mass nouns. Examples include: air, soil, or water. EnvO terms listed under environmental matter can be found from the link: http://bioportal.bioontology.org/visualize/1069/?conceptid=ENVO%3A00010483

elevation.definition: The elevation of the sampling site in meters as measured by the vertical distance from mean sea level.

collection_timezone.definition: The timezone of sampling.  Use ISO8601 compliant format, ie. UTC-7

collection_date.definition: The date of sampling. Use ISO8601 compliant format, ie. 2008-01-23

country.definition: The geographical origin of the sample as defined by the country or sea name. Country or sea names should be chosen from the INSDC country list (http://insdc.org/country.html), or the GAZ ontology (http://bioportal.bioontology.org/visualize/1397)

altitude.definition: The altitude of the sample is the vertical distance in meters between Earth's surface above Sea Level and the sampled position in the air.

env_package.definition: MIGS/MIMS/MIMARKS extension for reporting of measurements and observations obtained from one or more of the environments where the sample was obtained. Use one of: air, host-associated, human-associated, human-skin, human-oral, human-gut, human-vaginal, microbial mat|biofilm, miscellaneous, plant-associated, sediment, soil, wastewater|sludge, water

biome.definition: The environmental biome represents the major classes of ecologically similar communities of plants, animals, and other organisms. Biomes are defined based on factors such as plant structures, leaf types, plant spacing, and other factors like climate. Examples include: desert, taiga, deciduous woodland, or coral reef. EnvO terms listed under environmental biome can be found from the link: http://bioportal.bioontology.org/visualize/1069/?conceptid=ENVO%3A00000428

samp_collect_device.definition: The method or device employed for isolating/collecting the sample
samp_collect_device.value:
A total of 98 soil samples that were distinct with respect to soil and site characteristics were collected from a wide array of ecosystem types in North and South America (see Table 3). Only soils unsaturated for the majority of the year were examined. Soils were collected near the height of the plant growing season at each location. To examine whether seasonal variation was important, an additional set of soil samples was collected 6 months after the initial collection at a subset of sites. At each site, the upper 5 cm of mineral soil was collected from 5ÃÂ10 locations within a given plot of ≈100 m2 and composited into a single bulk sample. All soil samples were shipped to the University of California, Santa Barbara, within a few days of collection, where they were sieved to 4 mm, homogenized, and archived at ÃÂ80ÃÂ°C.

Approximately 10 g of soil from each site was homogenized in a mortar and pestle with liquid N2, and DNAs were extracted from a 0.5-g subsample by use of a MoBio PowerSoil DNA extraction kit following the manufacturer's instructions, with an additional incubation step at 65ÃÂ°C for 10 min followed by 2 min of bead beating to limit DNA shearing. Eluted DNAs were stored at −20ÃÂ°C.

material.definition: The environmental material level refers to the matter that was displaced by the sample, prior to the sampling event. Environmental matter terms are generally mass nouns. Examples include: air, soil, or water. EnvO terms listed under environmental matter can be found from the link: http://bioportal.bioontology.org/visualize/1069/?conceptid=ENVO%3A00010483

elevation.definition: The elevation of the sampling site in meters as measured by the vertical distance from mean sea level.

collection_timezone.definition: The timezone of sampling.  Use ISO8601 compliant format, ie. UTC-7

collection_date.definition: The date of sampling. Use ISO8601 compliant format, ie. 2008-01-23

country.definition: The geographical origin of the sample as defined by the country or sea name. Country or sea names should be chosen from the INSDC country list (http://insdc.org/country.html), or the GAZ ontology (http://bioportal.bioontology.org/visualize/1397)

altitude.definition: The altitude of the sample is the vertical distance in meters between Earth's surface above Sea Level and the sampled position in the air.

env_package.definition: MIGS/MIMS/MIMARKS extension for reporting of measurements and observations obtained from one or more of the environments where the sample was obtained. Use one of: air, host-associated, human-associated, human-skin, human-oral, human-gut, human-vaginal, microbial mat|biofilm, miscellaneous, plant-associated, sediment, soil, wastewater|sludge, water

samp_collect_device.definition: The method or device employed for isolating/collecting the sample
samp_collect_device.value:
A total of 98 soil samples that were distinct with respect to soil and site characteristics were collected from a wide array of ecosystem types in North and South America (see Table 3). Only soils unsaturated for the majority of the year were examined. Soils were collected near the height of the plant growing season at each location. To examine whether seasonal variation was important, an additional set of soil samples was collected 6 months after the initial collection at a subset of sites. At each site, the upper 5 cm of mineral soil was collected from 5ÃÂ10 locations within a given plot of ≈100 m2 and composited into a single bulk sample. All soil samples were shipped to the University of California, Santa Barbara, within a few days of collection, where they were sieved to 4 mm, homogenized, and archived at ÃÂ80ÃÂ°C.

Approximately 10 g of soil from each site was homogenized in a mortar and pestle with liquid N2, and DNAs were extracted from a 0.5-g subsample by use of a MoBio PowerSoil DNA extraction kit following the manufacturer's instructions, with an additional incubation step at 65ÃÂ°C for 10 min followed by 2 min of bead beating to limit DNA shearing. Eluted DNAs were stored at −20ÃÂ°C.

reverse_primers.definition: List of reverse PCR primers that were used to amplify the sequence of the targeted gene, locus or subfragment

metagenome_name.definition: Unique name for the sequences from this library
metagenome_name.value: IE1 Institute for Ecosystem Studies, NY

reverse_barcodes.definition: List of barcodes attached to reverse primers
reverse_barcodes.value: 338R primer contained a 12-bp bar-code sequence, a TC linker, and a Roche 454 B sequencing adapter

seq_meth.definition: Sequencing method used. Use one of: Sanger, pyrosequencing, ABI-solid, 454, Illumina, assembeled, other

forward_barcodes.definition: List of barcodes attached to forward primers

investigation_type.definition: Library construction type. This field is either metagenome for whole genome shotgun sequencing or mimarks-survey for amplicon/16S rRNA sequencing

sample_name.definition: Unique name or id of the sample the library is derived from

seq_center.definition: Name of instatute sequencing was done

target_gene.definition: Targeted gene or locus name for marker gene studies; e.g. 16S rRNA, 18S rRNA, nif, amoA, rpo

forward_primers.definition: List of forward PCR primers that were used to amplify the sequence of the targeted gene, locus or subfragment

biome.definition: The environmental biome represents the major classes of ecologically similar communities of plants, animals, and other organisms. Biomes are defined based on factors such as plant structures, leaf types, plant spacing, and other factors like climate. Examples include: desert, taiga, deciduous woodland, or coral reef. EnvO terms listed under environmental biome can be found from the link: http://bioportal.bioontology.org/visualize/1069/?conceptid=ENVO%3A00000428

samp_collect_device.definition: The method or device employed for isolating/collecting the sample
samp_collect_device.value:
A total of 98 soil samples that were distinct with respect to soil and site characteristics were collected from a wide array of ecosystem types in North and South America (see Table 3). Only soils unsaturated for the majority of the year were examined. Soils were collected near the height of the plant growing season at each location. To examine whether seasonal variation was important, an additional set of soil samples was collected 6 months after the initial collection at a subset of sites. At each site, the upper 5 cm of mineral soil was collected from 5ÃÂ10 locations within a given plot of ≈100 m2 and composited into a single bulk sample. All soil samples were shipped to the University of California, Santa Barbara, within a few days of collection, where they were sieved to 4 mm, homogenized, and archived at ÃÂ80ÃÂ°C.

Approximately 10 g of soil from each site was homogenized in a mortar and pestle with liquid N2, and DNAs were extracted from a 0.5-g subsample by use of a MoBio PowerSoil DNA extraction kit following the manufacturer's instructions, with an additional incubation step at 65ÃÂ°C for 10 min followed by 2 min of bead beating to limit DNA shearing. Eluted DNAs were stored at −20ÃÂ°C.

material.definition: The environmental material level refers to the matter that was displaced by the sample, prior to the sampling event. Environmental matter terms are generally mass nouns. Examples include: air, soil, or water. EnvO terms listed under environmental matter can be found from the link: http://bioportal.bioontology.org/visualize/1069/?conceptid=ENVO%3A00010483

elevation.definition: The elevation of the sampling site in meters as measured by the vertical distance from mean sea level.

collection_timezone.definition: The timezone of sampling.  Use ISO8601 compliant format, ie. UTC-7

collection_date.definition: The date of sampling. Use ISO8601 compliant format, ie. 2008-01-23

country.definition: The geographical origin of the sample as defined by the country or sea name. Country or sea names should be chosen from the INSDC country list (http://insdc.org/country.html), or the GAZ ontology (http://bioportal.bioontology.org/visualize/1397)

altitude.definition: The altitude of the sample is the vertical distance in meters between Earth's surface above Sea Level and the sampled position in the air.

env_package.definition: MIGS/MIMS/MIMARKS extension for reporting of measurements and observations obtained from one or more of the environments where the sample was obtained. Use one of: air, host-associated, human-associated, human-skin, human-oral, human-gut, human-vaginal, microbial mat|biofilm, miscellaneous, plant-associated, sediment, soil, wastewater|sludge, water

feature.definition: Environmental feature level includes geographic environmental features. Examples include: harbor, cliff, or lake. EnvO terms listed under environmental feature can be found from the link: http://bioportal.bioontology.org/visualize/1069/?conceptid=ENVO%3A00002297

longitude.definition: The geographical origin of the sample as defined by longitude. The value should be reported in decimal degrees and in WGS84 system

isol_growth_condt.definition: Publication reference in the form of pubmed ID (pmid), digital object identifier (doi) or url for isolation of the sample

depth.definition: Depth is defined as the vertical distance in meters below surface, e.g. for sediment or soil samples depth is measured from sediment or soil surface, respectivly.

samp_collect_device.definition: The method or device employed for isolating/collecting the sample
samp_collect_device.value:
A total of 98 soil samples that were distinct with respect to soil and site characteristics were collected from a wide array of ecosystem types in North and South America (see Table 3). Only soils unsaturated for the majority of the year were examined. Soils were collected near the height of the plant growing season at each location. To examine whether seasonal variation was important, an additional set of soil samples was collected 6 months after the initial collection at a subset of sites. At each site, the upper 5 cm of mineral soil was collected from 5ÃÂ10 locations within a given plot of ≈100 m2 and composited into a single bulk sample. All soil samples were shipped to the University of California, Santa Barbara, within a few days of collection, where they were sieved to 4 mm, homogenized, and archived at ÃÂ80ÃÂ°C.

Approximately 10 g of soil from each site was homogenized in a mortar and pestle with liquid N2, and DNAs were extracted from a 0.5-g subsample by use of a MoBio PowerSoil DNA extraction kit following the manufacturer's instructions, with an additional incubation step at 65ÃÂ°C for 10 min followed by 2 min of bead beating to limit DNA shearing. Eluted DNAs were stored at −20ÃÂ°C.

investigation_type.definition: Library construction type. This field is either metagenome for whole genome shotgun sequencing or mimarks-survey for amplicon/16S rRNA sequencing

sample_name.definition: Unique name or id of the sample the library is derived from

seq_center.definition: Name of instatute sequencing was done

target_gene.definition: Targeted gene or locus name for marker gene studies; e.g. 16S rRNA, 18S rRNA, nif, amoA, rpo

forward_primers.definition: List of forward PCR primers that were used to amplify the sequence of the targeted gene, locus or subfragment

biome.definition: The environmental biome represents the major classes of ecologically similar communities of plants, animals, and other organisms. Biomes are defined based on factors such as plant structures, leaf types, plant spacing, and other factors like climate. Examples include: desert, taiga, deciduous woodland, or coral reef. EnvO terms listed under environmental biome can be found from the link: http://bioportal.bioontology.org/visualize/1069/?conceptid=ENVO%3A00000428

samp_collect_device.definition: The method or device employed for isolating/collecting the sample
samp_collect_device.value:
A total of 98 soil samples that were distinct with respect to soil and site characteristics were collected from a wide array of ecosystem types in North and South America (see Table 3). Only soils unsaturated for the majority of the year were examined. Soils were collected near the height of the plant growing season at each location. To examine whether seasonal variation was important, an additional set of soil samples was collected 6 months after the initial collection at a subset of sites. At each site, the upper 5 cm of mineral soil was collected from 5ÃÂ10 locations within a given plot of ≈100 m2 and composited into a single bulk sample. All soil samples were shipped to the University of California, Santa Barbara, within a few days of collection, where they were sieved to 4 mm, homogenized, and archived at ÃÂ80ÃÂ°C.

Approximately 10 g of soil from each site was homogenized in a mortar and pestle with liquid N2, and DNAs were extracted from a 0.5-g subsample by use of a MoBio PowerSoil DNA extraction kit following the manufacturer's instructions, with an additional incubation step at 65ÃÂ°C for 10 min followed by 2 min of bead beating to limit DNA shearing. Eluted DNAs were stored at −20ÃÂ°C.

material.definition: The environmental material level refers to the matter that was displaced by the sample, prior to the sampling event. Environmental matter terms are generally mass nouns. Examples include: air, soil, or water. EnvO terms listed under environmental matter can be found from the link: http://bioportal.bioontology.org/visualize/1069/?conceptid=ENVO%3A00010483

elevation.definition: The elevation of the sampling site in meters as measured by the vertical distance from mean sea level.

collection_timezone.definition: The timezone of sampling.  Use ISO8601 compliant format, ie. UTC-7

collection_date.definition: The date of sampling. Use ISO8601 compliant format, ie. 2008-01-23

country.definition: The geographical origin of the sample as defined by the country or sea name. Country or sea names should be chosen from the INSDC country list (http://insdc.org/country.html), or the GAZ ontology (http://bioportal.bioontology.org/visualize/1397)

altitude.definition: The altitude of the sample is the vertical distance in meters between Earth's surface above Sea Level and the sampled position in the air.

env_package.definition: MIGS/MIMS/MIMARKS extension for reporting of measurements and observations obtained from one or more of the environments where the sample was obtained. Use one of: air, host-associated, human-associated, human-skin, human-oral, human-gut, human-vaginal, microbial mat|biofilm, miscellaneous, plant-associated, sediment, soil, wastewater|sludge, water

feature.definition: Environmental feature level includes geographic environmental features. Examples include: harbor, cliff, or lake. EnvO terms listed under environmental feature can be found from the link: http://bioportal.bioontology.org/visualize/1069/?conceptid=ENVO%3A00002297

longitude.definition: The geographical origin of the sample as defined by longitude. The value should be reported in decimal degrees and in WGS84 system

isol_growth_condt.definition: Publication reference in the form of pubmed ID (pmid), digital object identifier (doi) or url for isolation of the sample

depth.definition: Depth is defined as the vertical distance in meters below surface, e.g. for sediment or soil samples depth is measured from sediment or soil surface, respectivly.

location.definition: The geographical origin of the sample as defined by the specific local region name

country.definition: The geographical origin of the sample as defined by the country or sea name. Country or sea names should be chosen from the INSDC country list (http://insdc.org/country.html), or the GAZ ontology (http://bioportal.bioontology.org/visualize/1397)

altitude.definition: The altitude of the sample is the vertical distance in meters between Earth's surface above Sea Level and the sampled position in the air.

env_package.definition: MIGS/MIMS/MIMARKS extension for reporting of measurements and observations obtained from one or more of the environments where the sample was obtained. Use one of: air, host-associated, human-associated, human-skin, human-oral, human-gut, human-vaginal, microbial mat|biofilm, miscellaneous, plant-associated, sediment, soil, wastewater|sludge, water

feature.definition: Environmental feature level includes geographic environmental features. Examples include: harbor, cliff, or lake. EnvO terms listed under environmental feature can be found from the link: http://bioportal.bioontology.org/visualize/1069/?conceptid=ENVO%3A00002297

longitude.definition: The geographical origin of the sample as defined by longitude. The value should be reported in decimal degrees and in WGS84 system

isol_growth_condt.definition: Publication reference in the form of pubmed ID (pmid), digital object identifier (doi) or url for isolation of the sample

depth.definition: Depth is defined as the vertical distance in meters below surface, e.g. for sediment or soil samples depth is measured from sediment or soil surface, respectivly.

sample_name.definition: Unique name or id of the sample

continent.definition: The geographical origin of the sample as defined by continent.  Use one of: Africa, Antarctica, Asia, Australia, Europe, North America, South America

collection_time.definition: The local time of sampling.  Use ISO8601 compliant format, ie. 19:23:10

forward_barcodes.definition: List of barcodes attached to forward primers

sample_name.definition: Unique name or id of the sample the library is derived from

seq_center.definition: Name of instatute sequencing was done

target_gene.definition: Targeted gene or locus name for marker gene studies; e.g. 16S rRNA, 18S rRNA, nif, amoA, rpo

forward_primers.definition: List of forward PCR primers that were used to amplify the sequence of the targeted gene, locus or subfragment

biome.definition: The environmental biome represents the major classes of ecologically similar communities of plants, animals, and other organisms. Biomes are defined based on factors such as plant structures, leaf types, plant spacing, and other factors like climate. Examples include: desert, taiga, deciduous woodland, or coral reef. EnvO terms listed under environmental biome can be found from the link: http://bioportal.bioontology.org/visualize/1069/?conceptid=ENVO%3A00000428

samp_collect_device.definition: The method or device employed for isolating/collecting the sample
samp_collect_device.value:
A total of 98 soil samples that were distinct with respect to soil and site characteristics were collected from a wide array of ecosystem types in North and South America (see Table 3). Only soils unsaturated for the majority of the year were examined. Soils were collected near the height of the plant growing season at each location. To examine whether seasonal variation was important, an additional set of soil samples was collected 6 months after the initial collection at a subset of sites. At each site, the upper 5 cm of mineral soil was collected from 5-10 locations within a given plot of ≈100 m2 and composited into a single bulk sample. All soil samples were shipped to the University of California, Santa Barbara, within a few days of collection, where they were sieved to 4 mm, homogenized, and archived at -80C.

Approximately 10 g of soil from each site was homogenized in a mortar and pestle with liquid N2, and DNAs were extracted from a 0.5-g subsample by use of a MoBio PowerSoil DNA extraction kit following the manufacturer's instructions, with an additional incubation step at 65C for 10 min followed by 2 min of bead beating to limit DNA shearing. Eluted DNAs were stored at −20C.

material.definition: The environmental material level refers to the matter that was displaced by the sample, prior to the sampling event. Environmental matter terms are generally mass nouns. Examples include: air, soil, or water. EnvO terms listed under environmental matter can be found from the link: http://bioportal.bioontology.org/visualize/1069/?conceptid=ENVO%3A00010483

biome.definition: The environmental biome represents the major classes of ecologically similar communities of plants, animals, and other organisms. Biomes are defined based on factors such as plant structures, leaf types, plant spacing, and other factors like climate. Examples include: desert, taiga, deciduous woodland, or coral reef. EnvO terms listed under environmental biome can be found from the link: http://bioportal.bioontology.org/visualize/1069/?conceptid=ENVO%3A00000428

samp_collect_device.definition: The method or device employed for isolating/collecting the sample
samp_collect_device.value:
A total of 98 soil samples that were distinct with respect to soil and site characteristics were collected from a wide array of ecosystem types in North and South America (see Table 3). Only soils unsaturated for the majority of the year were examined. Soils were collected near the height of the plant growing season at each location. To examine whether seasonal variation was important, an additional set of soil samples was collected 6 months after the initial collection at a subset of sites. At each site, the upper 5 cm of mineral soil was collected from 5-10 locations within a given plot of ≈100 m2 and composited into a single bulk sample. All soil samples were shipped to the University of California, Santa Barbara, within a few days of collection, where they were sieved to 4 mm, homogenized, and archived at -80C.

Approximately 10 g of soil from each site was homogenized in a mortar and pestle with liquid N2, and DNAs were extracted from a 0.5-g subsample by use of a MoBio PowerSoil DNA extraction kit following the manufacturer's instructions, with an additional incubation step at 65C for 10 min followed by 2 min of bead beating to limit DNA shearing. Eluted DNAs were stored at −20C.

material.definition: The environmental material level refers to the matter that was displaced by the sample, prior to the sampling event. Environmental matter terms are generally mass nouns. Examples include: air, soil, or water. EnvO terms listed under environmental matter can be found from the link: http://bioportal.bioontology.org/visualize/1069/?conceptid=ENVO%3A00010483

elevation.definition: The elevation of the sampling site in meters as measured by the vertical distance from mean sea level.

collection_timezone.definition: The timezone of sampling.  Use ISO8601 compliant format, ie. UTC-7

collection_date.definition: The date of sampling. Use ISO8601 compliant format, ie. 2008-01-23

country.definition: The geographical origin of the sample as defined by the country or sea name. Country or sea names should be chosen from the INSDC country list (http://insdc.org/country.html), or the GAZ ontology (http://bioportal.bioontology.org/visualize/1397)

altitude.definition: The altitude of the sample is the vertical distance in meters between Earth's surface above Sea Level and the sampled position in the air.

env_package.definition: MIGS/MIMS/MIMARKS extension for reporting of measurements and observations obtained from one or more of the environments where the sample was obtained. Use one of: air, host-associated, human-associated, human-skin, human-oral, human-gut, human-vaginal, microbial mat|biofilm, miscellaneous, plant-associated, sediment, soil, wastewater|sludge, water

feature.definition: Environmental feature level includes geographic environmental features. Examples include: harbor, cliff, or lake. EnvO terms listed under environmental feature can be found from the link: http://bioportal.bioontology.org/visualize/1069/?conceptid=ENVO%3A00002297

longitude.definition: The geographical origin of the sample as defined by longitude. The value should be reported in decimal degrees and in WGS84 system

isol_growth_condt.definition: Publication reference in the form of pubmed ID (pmid), digital object identifier (doi) or url for isolation of the sample

depth.definition: Depth is defined as the vertical distance in meters below surface, e.g. for sediment or soil samples depth is measured from sediment or soil surface, respectivly.

biome.definition: The environmental biome represents the major classes of ecologically similar communities of plants, animals, and other organisms. samp_collect_device.definition: The method or device employed for isolating/collecting the sample
samp_collect_device.value:
A total of 98 soil samples that were distinct with respect to soil and site characteristics were collected from a wide array of ecosystem types in North and South America (see Table 3). Only soils unsaturated for the majority of the year were examined. Soils were collected near the height of the plant growing season at each location. To examine whether seasonal variation was important, an additional set of soil samples was collected 6 months after the initial collection at a subset of sites. At each site, the upper 5 cm of mineral soil was collected from 5-10 locations within a given plot of ≈100 m2 and composited into a single bulk sample. All soil samples were shipped to the University of California, Santa Barbara, within a few days of collection, where they were sieved to 4 mm, homogenized, and archived at -80C.

Approximately 10 g of soil from each site was homogenized in a mortar and pestle with liquid N2, and DNAs were extracted from a 0.5-g subsample by use of a MoBio PowerSoil DNA extraction kit following the manufacturer's instructions, with an additional incubation step at 65C for 10 min followed by 2 min of bead beating to limit DNA shearing. Eluted DNAs were stored at −20C.

material.definition: The environmental material level refers to the matter that was displaced by the sample, prior to the sampling event. Environmental matter terms are generally mass nouns. Examples include: air, soil, or water. EnvO terms listed under environmental matter can be found from the link: http://bioportal.bioontology.org/visualize/1069/?conceptid=ENVO%3A00010483

elevation.definition: The elevation of the sampling site in meters as measured by the vertical distance from mean sea level.

collection_timezone.definition: The timezone of sampling.  Use ISO8601 compliant format, ie. UTC-7

collection_date.definition: The date of sampling. Use ISO8601 compliant format, ie. 2008-01-23

country.definition: The geographical origin of the sample as defined by the country or sea name. Country or sea names should be chosen from the INSDC country list (http://insdc.org/country.html), or the GAZ ontology (http://bioportal.bioontology.org/visualize/1397)

altitude.definition: The altitude of the sample is the vertical distance in meters between Earth's surface above Sea Level and the sampled position in the air.

env_package.definition: MIGS/MIMS/MIMARKS extension for reporting of measurements and observations obtained from one or more of the environments where the sample was obtained. Use one of: air, host-associated, human-associated, human-skin, human-oral, human-gut, human-vaginal, microbial mat|biofilm, miscellaneous, plant-associated, sediment, soil, wastewater|sludge, water

Approximately 10 g of soil from each site was homogenized in a mortar and pestle with liquid N2, and DNAs were extracted from a 0.5-g subsample by use of a MoBio PowerSoil DNA extraction kit following the manufacturer's instructions, with an additional incubation step at 65C for 10 min followed by 2 min of bead beating to limit DNA shearing. Eluted DNAs were stored at −20C.

Eluted DNAs were stored at −20C.

seq_meth.definition: Sequencing method used. Use one of: Sanger, pyrosequencing, ABI-solid, 454, Illumina, assembeled, other

forward_barcodes.definition: List of barcodes attached to forward primers

investigation_type.definition: Library construction type. This field is either metagenome for whole genome shotgun sequencing or mimarks-survey for amplicon/16S rRNA sequencing

sample_name.definition: Unique name or id of the sample the library is derived from

seq_center.definition: Name of instatute sequencing was done

target_gene.definition: Targeted gene or locus name for marker gene studies; e.g. 16S rRNA, 18S rRNA, nif, amoA, rpo

forward_primers.definition: List of forward PCR primers that were used to amplify the sequence of the targeted gene, locus or subfragment

biome.definition: The environmental biome represents the major classes of ecologically similar communities of plants, animals, and other organisms. Biomes are defined based on factors such as plant structures, leaf types, plant spacing, and other factors like climate. Examples include: desert, taiga, deciduous woodland, or coral reef. EnvO terms listed under environmental biome can be found from the link: http://bioportal.bioontology.org/visualize/1069/?conceptid=ENVO%3A00000428

samp_collect_device.definition: The method or device employed for isolating/collecting the sample
samp_collect_device.value:
A total of 98 soil samples that were distinct with respect to soil and site characteristics were collected from a wide array of ecosystem types in North and South America (see Table 3). Only soils unsaturated for the majority of the year were examined. Soils were collected near the height of the plant growing season at each location. To examine whether seasonal variation was important, an additional set of soil samples was collected 6 months after the initial collection at a subset of sites. At each site, the upper 5 cm of mineral soil was collected from 5-10 locations within a given plot of ≈100 m2 and composited into a single bulk sample. All soil samples were shipped to the University of California, Santa Barbara, within a few days of collection, where they were sieved to 4 mm, homogenized, and archived at -80C.

Approximately 10 g of soil from each site was homogenized in a mortar and pestle with liquid N2, and DNAs were extracted from a 0.5-g subsample by use of a MoBio PowerSoil DNA extraction kit following the manufacturer's instructions, with an additional incubation step at 65C for 10 min followed by 2 min of bead beating to limit DNA shearing. Eluted DNAs were stored at −20C.

material.definition: The environmental material level refers to the matter that was displaced by the sample, prior to the sampling event. Environmental matter terms are generally mass nouns. Examples include: air, soil, or water. EnvO terms listed under environmental matter can be found from the link: http://bioportal.bioontology.org/visualize/1069/?conceptid=ENVO%3A00010483

elevation.definition: The elevation of the sampling site in meters as measured by the vertical distance from mean sea level.

collection_timezone.definition: The timezone of sampling.  Use ISO8601 compliant format, ie. UTC-7

collection_date.definition: The date of sampling. Use ISO8601 compliant format, ie. 2008-01-23

country.definition: The geographical origin of the sample as defined by the country or sea name. Country or sea names should be chosen from the INSDC country list (http://insdc.org/country.html), or the GAZ ontology (http://bioportal.bioontology.org/visualize/1397)

altitude.definition: The altitude of the sample is the vertical distance in meters between Earth's surface above Sea Level and the sampled position in the air.

env_package.definition: MIGS/MIMS/MIMARKS extension for reporting of measurements and observations obtained from one or more of the environments where the sample was obtained. Use one of: air, host-associated, human-associated, human-skin, human-oral, human-gut, human-vaginal, microbial mat|biofilm, miscellaneous, plant-associated, sediment, soil, wastewater|sludge, water

feature.definition: Environmental feature level includes geographic environmental features. Examples include: harbor, cliff, or lake. EnvO terms listed under environmental feature can be found from the link: http://bioportal.bioontology.org/visualize/1069/?conceptid=ENVO%3A00002297

longitude.definition: The geographical origin of the sample as defined by longitude. The value should be reported in decimal degrees and in WGS84 system

isol_growth_condt.definition: Publication reference in the form of pubmed ID (pmid), digital object identifier (doi) or url for isolation of the sample

depth.definition: Depth is defined as the vertical distance in meters below surface, e.g. for sediment or soil samples depth is measured from sediment or soil surface, respectivly.

location.definition: The geographical origin of the sample as defined by the specific local region name

sample_name.definition: Unique name or id of the sample

latitude.definition: The geographical origin of the sample as defined by latitude. The value should be reported in decimal degrees and in WGS84 system

samp_size.definition: Amount or size of sample (volume, mass or area) that was collected, along with the unit used

continent.definition: The geographical origin of the sample as defined by continent.  Use one of: Africa, Antarctica, Asia, Australia, Europe, North America, South America

collection_time.definition: The local time of sampling.  Use ISO8601 compliant format, ie. 19:23:10
